attributes.title: Impact of ecological park restoration on health in low income neighborhoods: A natural experiment
attributes.description: OSF registration of Study of Active Neighborhoods in Detroit (StAND): a natural experiment evaluating the health benefits of ecological restoration of parks

q1.value: Impacts of ecological park restoration on health in low income neighborhoods: A natural experiment

q3.value: Individuals living in socioeconomically deprived inner cities have disproportionately high rates of cardiovascular disease, cancers, Type 2 diabetes and obesity, which have stress- and physical inactivity-related etiologies. Previous research on the urban built environment suggests that parks may reduce stress and increase physical activity. Yet, the causal health relationships have been difficult to establish. The aims of this study are to observe the effects of ecological restoration of parks on physical activity, stress and cardio-metabolic health outcomes from baseline through 3-years post-restoration using a quasi-experimental design. This study has implications for public health planning, where small changes in neighborhood green spaces may have large benefits for low-income neighborhood health outcomes.

q4.value:
Hypothesis 1: Compared to participants in control (CNT) park neighborhoods, participants in intervention (INT) park neighborhoods will have increased physical activity (PA) levels at three-years post-restoration. 
Hypothesis 2: Compared to participants in CNT park neighborhoods, participants in INT park neighborhoods will have increased levels of ‘green PA’ at three-years post-restoration. 
Hypothesis 3: Across both INT and CNT parks, the quality of visual and auditory exposures (positive and negative) will affect PA levels. 
Hypothesis 4: Compared to participants in CNT park neighborhoods, participants in INT park neighborhoods will have lower stress levels as indexed by measures of cortisol, perceived stress, and anxiety at three-years post-restoration. 
Hypothesis 5: Participants with higher levels of PA and ‘green PA’ will have lower stress. 
Hypothesis 6: The quality of visual and auditory exposures (positive and negative) will affect stress levels. 
Hypothesis 7: Compared to participants in CNT park neighborhoods, participants in INT park neighborhoods will have improved glycated hemoglobin A1C (A1C) and C-reactive protein (CRP) at three-years post-restoration. 
Hypothesis 8: Compared to participants in CNT park neighborhoods, participants in INT park neighborhoods will have lower blood pressure, body mass index (BMI), and hip-to-waist ratios at three-years post-restoration.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.
Personnel who interact directly with the study subjects (either human or non-human subjects) will not be aware of the assigned treatments. (Commonly known as “double blind”)

question.value: The overall design of StAND is a four-year quasi-experimental, natural experiment, with two conditions (intervention and control), four measurement occasions, and individual-level measurement of exposures and outcomes.

q9.value: N/A. This is a quasi-experimental design; a natural experiment.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

q11.value: We conducted a feasibility study in 2018 and began recruitment for the parent study in 2019. However, due to a truncated field season, recruitment will begin in earnest in May 2020. Data are not yet processed or stored in a database.

question.value:
Participants. Participants are adults who reside in a study park’s zone of influence, which is deemed to be 0.5km (0.31mi), which is an approximate 15-minute walk to the park and also a reasonable maximum distance for hearing birdsong in an urban setting. Participants will be recruited from within a 16-cell grid (120m2/cell) around each park. Thus, the unit of measurement is the individual, but the unit of assignment-to-intervention is neighborhood. We conducted a pilot study in two neighborhoods in 2018 (n = 69 participants enrolled) and received funding at the end of the summer in 2019, yielding a truncated field season (n=170 participants). The first full field season for this study will be 2020. To recruit participants, we mail postcards and conduct recruitment activities (e.g., information booths) in each neighborhood. Field staff then visit homes in each study neighborhood to brief potential participants on the study, request participation, and screen for inclusion. We recruit only one English-speaking male or female (≥ 18y) without mobility issues per household, which is at the household’s discretion. To ensure participant comprehension and confirm contact information, we use an electronic text message to finalize enrollment. Participants are then instructed on the correct usage of the accelerometer (Actigraph GT3X), Global Positioning System (GPS) device (Canmore) and cortisol sample collection and instructed that a study shuttle will take them to their scheduled health appointment in our study office. The target total sample is 450 adults to be recruited and retained. To retain participants, we will employ a set of strategies including: 1) sending holiday cards with neighborhood-level results; 2) sending birthday cards; and 3) sending periodic, brief surveys through StANDApp.

Physical activity (primary outcome) measured using accelerometry. PA and sedentary behavior are measured using the ActiGraph accelerometer (ActiGraph model GT3X; Pensacola, FL). The ActiGraph is a triaxial accelerometer that measures acceleration in three planes of motion. Accelerometers capture and filter acceleration signals that are digitized and recorded as count values that are stored in investigator-defined intervals. Raw data are stored and may also be used for analyses. The accelerometers will be worn on an elastic waistband, placed at the right hip, for all waking hours over seven days at each of the study’s four measurement time points (all during the summer or early autumn). Data will be collected in raw mode (30 Hz) and aggregated to 1-min values for analyses. The primary outcome is total PA counts per week, which has been associated with cardio-metabolic outcomes and biomarkers. Analyses will also include number of minutes spent at given PA intensity levels using cut-points of Freedson et al. (≥1952 counts/min) for moderate-to-vigorous intensity PA and Matthews et al. (<100 counts/min) for sedentary behavior, with light PA as 100-1951 counts/min. We will also explore PA intensity levels using vector magnitude cutpoints. In addition, these measures will be stratified by whether the PA occurred in the study park, in any greenspace, or elsewhere (based on GPS data). This will provide an indication of the proportion of ‘green PA’ from total PA. Periods of 60 minutes or more of continuous zeroes are considered non-wear times and not included in the calculation of total wear time. To be included, we will require ≥4 days of PA data (wear time ≥8-10 hr/day) per time point. If high levels of missing data exist, imputation strategies will be utilized. PA data will be collected at the same time of year (summer months only) to account for seasonality.

Mobility and park contact measured using GPS data. GPS units (Canmore) will be worn for one week, on an elastic belt with an accelerometer. At the end of the week of observation, data will be downloaded. To calculate the amount of time spent in ‘green PA’, these data will be linked with accelerometer data using time. Accelerometer data are then restricted using a threshold for PA and lux (>400). Speed is calculated and data are further restricted by excluding speeds >25kmph. This results in total green PA. We will also use GPS data to calculate the actual contact time spent within view of the park and usage of park. To calculate time spent within view of park, we will create ‘viewsheds’ around each park to determine all possible viewpoints from which the park can be seen, accounting for obstacles such as buildings, as we have done previously. To calculate usage of park, all GPS points located within 10m of the park boundaries will be compiled to calculate time spent in park.

Stress measures (secondary outcome). We will measure salivary cortisol, perceived stress and anxiety. Stress alters the dynamics of the diurnal rhythm of cortisol secretion, and people who are chronically stressed exhibit lower morning and higher evening concentrations, yielding flattened slopes. Samples will be collected using the passive drool method at waking, and 12-hr after waking to permit calculation of time point concentrations and the slope of cortisol from waking to evening. The saliva collection kit contains collection supplies, a response sheet and reminder instructions. Participants will be reminded to take and freeze samples at designated times the day before their scheduled health appointment via StANDApp and/or text. Participants will also be reminded to bring kits to their appointment the next day. In the field, samples will be stored in a manual-defrost freezer and shipped on dry ice (once per measurement period) to Northwestern University’s Laboratory for Human Biology Research where they will be thawed, centrifuged and the supernatant aliquoted into replicate samples in smaller tubes and analyzed in duplicate. Low, medium, and high concentration controls will be prepared in at t=0 for use throughout the study to monitor inter-assay variability. Cortisol will be measured using the Salimetrics ELISA kit as per manufacturer’s instructions.

We will also use two stress indicators via the survey, including: 1) Anxiety and Depression, measured via NIH’s Adult PROMIS-29 Profile v2.0; and 2) the Perceived Stress Scale, comprising 10 items (e.g., feeling nervous) measured on Likert-type scale (0=low, 40=max stress). The perceived stress scale has been validated in multiple populations, and the face validity and scale content were ranked high with a Kaiser-Meyer-Olkin coefficient of 0.82. The scale’s internal consistency reliability was good in multiple languages and convergent validity was supported by expected relationships with other mental health measures, including anxiety and depression. The PROMIS-29’s (our measures of anxiety and depressive symptoms) internal consistency for sub-domains has been shown to be high (Cronbach's α > 0.88), with adequate structural validity for most domains (CFI > 0.95, RMSEA < 0.05) (78).

Anthropometric and cardio-metabolic measures (downstream outcomes).  Cardio-metabolic outcomes will include body mass index (BMI), waist-to-hip ratio, blood pressure, glycated hemoglobin A1C (A1C) and C-reactive protein (CRP). Height will be measured twice using a stadiometer (SECA Corp). Weight will be measured twice using a scale with bioelectric impedance capability (Tanita TBF-300). Waist and hip measurements will be taken twice with a Gulick tape, according to World Health Organization (WHO) procedures and the waist-to-hip ratio calculated. Systolic and diastolic blood pressures will be measured as markers of cardiovascular disease (CVD) risk using an automatic upper arm monitor (Omron HEM-711DLX), according to American College of Cardiology recommendations (80). With the patient seated, two blood pressure measurements will be taken at 30 second intervals. The average of each set of measurements will be used for height, weight, waist and hip measurements and blood pressure. BMI will be calculated and expressed as kg/m2. A1C will be measured from blood samples collected from finger-tip sticks using portable analyzers and test strips (A1CNow+). Participants will be given these results immediately, including normal ranges and recommendations for consulting a physician. CRP will be measured to indicate chronic inflammation, associated with obesity, Type 2 diabetes, cancer, and CVD. DBS samples will be collected on Whatman 903 Protein Saver Cards from finger sticks following collection of blood for the A1C analyses. DBS serves as the lowest risk, least invasive blood sampling technique. Circulating levels of CRP in young, healthy adults average 0.8 mg/l. Chronic stress induces small changes in the range of 2-5 ng/l necessitating the use of high-sensitivity assays for CRP. Upon collection of DBS, samples will be transferred to Northwestern University’s Laboratory for Human Biology Research where CRP will be eluted from the DBS and assayed using a CRP assay previously validated in their laboratory for use with DBS. To reduce inter-assay variability and improve quality control, all samples will be stored with humidity sponges and oxygen absorbents and frozen (-20°C) until the final data collection year (2022) and then analyzed concurrently, with no expected degradation.

Survey. Basic demographic data information (age, sex, ethnicity, employment, household composition, length of residence) will be collected at recruitment or when re-contacted at each timepoint. Then, each participant will complete a self-administered paper survey in the privacy of their own home to assess: income, perceptions of the neighborhood, disease and prescription medication history, diet, perceived stress, anxiety and depression symptoms (discussed previously), nature-relatedness; all which were considered potential correlates of device-based PA and stress. Questions about the perceptions of the social and environmental features of neighborhoods have been shown to have moderate to high agreement (rho range=0.42-0.91). Family Life, Activity, Sun, Health, and Eating (FLASHE) questions related to diet were reviewed by the scientific experts for consistency with existing, validated measures. The nature-relatedness scale (NR-6) has been shown to demonstrate good internal consistency, temporal stability, and predict happiness, environmental concern, and nature contact. Measures that may serve as confounders include: 1) symptoms of acute illness or infection or prescription medication which could influence biomarker measures; 2) attitudes toward nature using the NR-6, because these may influence behaviors; and 3) perceived safety which may influence stress, PA, and park usage.

Park observations and imagery. The positive visual exposures of interest include the presence of people using the park, signage, mowing and other signs of care, diversity of plants and birds and greenness. Negative visual exposures include the presence of litter, arson, graffiti and broken windows of buildings along the park perimeter (called signs of disorder). We will employ two methods to obtain these data. First, Audubon volunteers will inventory plants in quadrants and count bird species using point counts less than three hours after sunrise, measuring species abundances. Volunteers will be trained by Audubon, and inter-observer reliability assessed by having two or more observers collect data simultaneously but independently. Plant/bird species richness and biodiversity measurement will employ the well-established Shannon Diversity and Simpson Indexes and Evar Evenness Index. Trained graduate students will also make observations of signs of care and the System for Observing Play and Recreation in Communities (SOPARC). SOPARC provides an assessment of park users’ PA levels, gender, activity types, and estimated age and ethnicity groupings as well as information on a park’s level of accessibility, usability, supervision, and organization with a high internal correlation between items (r=0.75), and exhibiting high inter-rater reliability (0.80-0.99). All nine parks, each of which consists of only one target area due their small size, will be observed twice over one day (9am-2pm) during randomly scheduled days without rain in summer months, by two raters. INT and CNT parks will be observed at the same time on different days for parallel observations. Signs of care involve observations (presence/absence) of manmade and natural items in a park and provides a categorical quality rating for each item, which is based on qualitative work in Detroit. Second, we will measure visual greenness and negative visual exposures (signs of disorder) via 360° images captured along each park perimeter, using a mounted camera (Samsung Gear 360). Images will be used to measure visual greenness, by quantifying pixels of greenery using methods we developed. Images will also be used to assess negative exposures using Marco et al.’s neighbor disorder coding protocol, which has shown acceptable ICCs (0.41-0.60) for the mean level of subscales of physical disorder and decay and has also been validated (showing high correlations) with physical audits, police impressions, and neighborhood socioeconomic status. This virtual auditing approach has been validated across several samples. We will employ two weighting schemes to create individual-level visual exposures from the park measures. First, we will weight each exposure by the actual contact time spent within view of the park in the one-week observation time using the GPS data as described previously. Second, we will calculate the percentage of the viewshed occupied by the park, as seen from the participant’s home by capturing a 360° image from the front door of the home location. We will then create weights using these measures, to be applied to each of the visual exposures above. 

Neighborhood soundscapes. Positive and negative auditory exposures will be assessed by acoustic recordings collected by 90 AudioMoth v1.1.0 acoustic loggers (Open Acoustic Devices).  Nine devices will be placed at least 100 m apart randomly in a 500 m grid around each park, and one device will be placed inside each park. We will record for one week in June, corresponding with Audubon’s bird surveys, selecting days to standardize weather conditions. To predict negative auditory exposure, we will calculate environmental noise metrics known to relate to human annoyance, health, and perception including: LAeq,T (A-weighted equivalent sound level (L) over time); LAmax (maximum A-weighted equivalent L over time); LA10 and LA90 (A-weighted L exceeded 10 and 90% of time); LA10 - LA90, LDN (Day-Night average L, where night events receive a 10dB penalty); LDEN (Day-Evening-High equivalency L); roughness (temporal variation in amplitude), and sharpness (126-129). 
To examine positive auditory exposure, trained staff will count the number and duration of sound categories using observations of spectrograms in Raven Pro software (Cornell University, Ithaca, NY). Sound categories are ‘anthropogenic’ (e.g., vehicle, people), ‘geological’ (e.g., wind), and ‘biological’ (e.g., birdsong). Additionally, we will further categorize bird song to species, in order to generate species richness and diversity of the acoustic community. We will combine the duration/frequency and richness of biological with geological sounds into a metric of positive exposure. Using values of each acoustic exposure metric, we will then predict levels throughout the study area using spatial kriging models. We will extract the positive and negative exposure levels for participants at each time point. 

Weather data. While we restrict data collection to summer months (May-September), weather conditions at the time of data collection and the two weeks prior to data collection may influence both exposures of interest and outcomes. Thus, we will compile daily precipitation and high temperature data for every day during data collection and the two weeks preceding data collection for each time point, from the weather station at Detroit airport (DTW).

q13.value: With a total of 9 parks (4 in INT, 5 in CNT), we will need a sample of 450 participants, or 50 per park, to detect EF = 0.35 with 82% power, based on a two-sided test at significance level 5%. Because attrition is expected over the study period, we will recruit a total of 620 participants at t=0 (baseline) to account for attrition of 15% at t=1 and another 10% at t=2 and 5% at t=3.

q14.value: Assuming a longitudinal panel design, sample size assessments for the study are based on achieving 82% power to test the hypotheses. The effect measure is a difference-in-differences (DID) — in hypotheses 1-3, i.e., the expected change in PA from baseline to three-years post-restoration in INT parks compared to the corresponding change in CNT parks. Hypotheses 3-6 concern a DID in stress outcomes. A review of the literature on PA and cortisol suggests an effect size (EF) of 0.35 could be posited. Accordingly, we calculate our sample size requirements to detect an EF of 0.35 or better with 82% power. Two other design features are: a serial correlation r between repeated measures over time and intra-class correlation (ICC) p for clustering within neighborhood parks. In community-intervention studies such as ours, p is small. Plausible values from the literature and our own experiences, suggest r ≥ 0.35 and p ≤ 0.004. Our sample size assessment may also be deemed conservative as it does not account for potential influence of fixed covariates, which should increase precision on the intervention effect estimate by reducing residual variance resulting in a positive effect on power.

question.value: n/a
Refer to the attached Table 1 for the tools, scale of measurement, and measurements that will be obtained annually 2019-2024.

Assuming a longitudinal panel design, we will compare intervention parks (INT) to control parks (CNT) at baseline using as appropriate ANOVA-F-tests, chi-square tests and non-parametric tests to determine equivalence of potentially confounding physiological and contextual participant characteristics. If substantive differences are found, they will be controlled for in subsequent analyses by regression techniques, guided by the degree of dissimilarity. Equivalence between groups will be assessed on age, sex, ethnicity, employment status, length of residence, marital status, attitudes towards nature, perceived safety, and pre-existing health conditions. We will calculate descriptive statistics for all variables at baseline and each post-restoration time point. Likewise, park characteristics will be summarized for the intervention and control parks for each time point.

We adopt a regression-based approach to multivariable modeling that addresses features of clustering of participants within parks and correlation over time in repeated assessments. Repeated measures ANOVA, or more apropos, generalized linear (mixed) models (GLMM) will be used. Denoted by an outcome in the i-th participant in the h-th park assessed at time t. It is assumed that an individual is primarily exposed to one park. Generally, outcomes are assessed at baseline and at least 3 additional time-points. The covariates are participant characteristics, some of which are time-invariant such as the aforementioned sociodemographic variables. Minimally, the predictor variables are: a single indicator for GROUP, with CNT as referent, three indicators for TIME, corresponding to t=1, 2, 3 with baseline t=0 as referent, and GROUPxTIME interactions. A measure of exposure to environmental stimuli is included in participant characteristics. The GLMM allows us to formulate and test hypotheses on functions of the regression parameters, including:  i) point-in-time comparison between INT and CNT, e.g., at each follow-up year;  ii) time-averaged comparison between INT and CNT;  iii) within group comparison for change over time; and  iv) change in INT compared to the corresponding change in CNT via DID. SAS Software v9.4 (Analytics 15.1 or higher) will be used for statistical analyses.
 
 Below, we outline specific analyses for each hypothesis to be tested.

Hypothesis 1: We will separately evaluate average activity counts/minute and average moderate-to-vigorous minutes over the one-week observation period for each of the data collection periods. The predictor of interest is binary: INT versus CNT.
Hypothesis 2: The primary outcome, ‘green PA’, will be average activity counts/minute and average moderate-to-vigorous minutes over the one-week observation period while in parks and greenspaces in Detroit, as a subset of all activity.
Hypothesis 3: We hypothesize there will be an association between PA and the visual and auditory exposures. Instead of a binary predictor of interest, we will use continuous predictors for visual and auditory park exposures. Interaction terms between positive and negative exposures will also be assessed, as evidence suggests that negative sounds deplete the restorative benefits of natural sounds, and that parks are often dominated by noise. 
Hypothesis 4: Each stress outcome will be evaluated separately and treated continuously. We will also explore potential mediators (e.g., PA) by adding each to mixed models as fixed terms, and adjusted mediation and partial correlation coefficients explored. We will adjust for prescription medication history and symptoms of acute illness as potential confounders.
Hypothesis 5: We will assess relationships with each stress indicator, in turn.
Hypothesis 6: We hypothesize there will be an association between each stress indicator and these exposures. 
Hypothesis 7: We will compare INT and CNT groups from baseline through three-years post-restoration for changes in CRP and A1C (continuously measured) between INT and CNT groups. We will also consider the inclusion of prescription medication history and symptoms of acute illness as potential confounders.
Hypothesis 8: We will compare INT and CNT groups from baseline through three-years post-restoration for changes in blood pressure, hip-to-waist ratio and BMI (continuously measured) between INT and CNT groups.

q23.value: To address missingness in our response data, we will employ strategies for imputation. The techniques described above allow missing at random (MAR). Inverse probability weighting will be investigated to accommodate missing data patterns that are not MAR. To minimize bias in analysis, we will adjust for factors that may be unbalanced between groups and examine the robustness of our conclusions under deviations of model assumptions.

Participants will be reminded to take and freeze samples at designated times the day before their scheduled health appointment via StANDApp and/or text. Participants will also be reminded to bring kits to their appointment the next day. In the field, samples will be stored in a manual-defrost freezer and shipped on dry ice (once per measurement period) to Northwestern University’s Laboratory for Human Biology Research where they will be thawed, centrifuged and the supernatant aliquoted into replicate samples in smaller tubes and analyzed in duplicate. Low, medium, and high concentration controls will be prepared in at t=0 for use throughout the study to monitor inter-assay variability. Cortisol will be measured using the Salimetrics ELISA kit as per manufacturer’s instructions.

We will also use two stress indicators via the survey, including: 1) Anxiety and Depression, measured via NIH’s Adult PROMIS-29 Profile v2.0; and 2) the Perceived Stress Scale, comprising 10 items (e.g., feeling nervous) measured on Likert-type scale (0=low, 40=max stress). The perceived stress scale has been validated in multiple populations, and the face validity and scale content were ranked high with a Kaiser-Meyer-Olkin coefficient of 0.82. The scale’s internal consistency reliability was good in multiple languages and convergent validity was supported by expected relationships with other mental health measures, including anxiety and depression. The PROMIS-29’s (our measures of anxiety and depressive symptoms) internal consistency for sub-domains has been shown to be high (Cronbach's α > 0.88), with adequate structural validity for most domains (CFI > 0.95, RMSEA < 0.05) (78).

Anthropometric and cardio-metabolic measures (downstream outcomes).  Cardio-metabolic outcomes will include body mass index (BMI), waist-to-hip ratio, blood pressure, glycated hemoglobin A1C (A1C) and C-reactive protein (CRP). Height will be measured twice using a stadiometer (SECA Corp). Weight will be measured twice using a scale with bioelectric impedance capability (Tanita TBF-300). Waist and hip measurements will be taken twice with a Gulick tape, according to World Health Organization (WHO) procedures and the waist-to-hip ratio calculated. Systolic and diastolic blood pressures will be measured as markers of cardiovascular disease (CVD) risk using an automatic upper arm monitor (Omron HEM-711DLX), according to American College of Cardiology recommendations (80). With the patient seated, two blood pressure measurements will be taken at 30 second intervals. The average of each set of measurements will be used for height, weight, waist and hip measurements and blood pressure. BMI will be calculated and expressed as kg/m2. A1C will be measured from blood samples collected from finger-tip sticks using portable analyzers and test strips (A1CNow+). Participants will be given these results immediately, including normal ranges and recommendations for consulting a physician. CRP will be measured to indicate chronic inflammation, associated with obesity, Type 2 diabetes, cancer, and CVD. DBS samples will be collected on Whatman 903 Protein Saver Cards from finger sticks following collection of blood for the A1C analyses. DBS serves as the lowest risk, least invasive blood sampling technique. Circulating levels of CRP in young, healthy adults average 0.8 mg/l. Chronic stress induces small changes in the range of 2-5 ng/l necessitating the use of high-sensitivity assays for CRP. Upon collection of DBS, samples will be transferred to Northwestern University’s Laboratory for Human Biology Research where CRP will be eluted from the DBS and assayed using a CRP assay previously validated in their laboratory for use with DBS. To reduce inter-assay variability and improve quality control, all samples will be stored with humidity sponges and oxygen absorbents and frozen (-20°C) until the final data collection year (2022) and then analyzed concurrently, with no expected degradation.

Survey. Basic demographic data information (age, sex, ethnicity, employment, household composition, length of residence) will be collected at recruitment or when re-contacted at each timepoint. Then, each participant will complete a self-administered paper survey in the privacy of their own home to assess: income, perceptions of the neighborhood, disease and prescription medication history, diet, perceived stress, anxiety and depression symptoms (discussed previously), nature-relatedness; all which were considered potential correlates of device-based PA and stress. Questions about the perceptions of the social and environmental features of neighborhoods have been shown to have moderate to high agreement (rho range=0.42-0.91). Family Life, Activity, Sun, Health, and Eating (FLASHE) questions related to diet were reviewed by the scientific experts for consistency with existing, validated measures. The nature-relatedness scale (NR-6) has been shown to demonstrate good internal consistency, temporal stability, and predict happiness, environmental concern, and nature contact. Measures that may serve as confounders include: 1) symptoms of acute illness or infection or prescription medication which could influence biomarker measures; 2) attitudes toward nature using the NR-6, because these may influence behaviors; and 3) perceived safety which may influence stress, PA, and park usage.

Park observations and imagery. The positive visual exposures of interest include the presence of people using the park, signage, mowing and other signs of care, diversity of plants and birds and greenness. Negative visual exposures include the presence of litter, arson, graffiti and broken windows of buildings along the park perimeter (called signs of disorder). We will employ two methods to obtain these data. First, Audubon volunteers will inventory plants in quadrants and count bird species using point counts less than three hours after sunrise, measuring species abundances. Volunteers will be trained by Audubon, and inter-observer reliability assessed by having two or more observers collect data simultaneously but independently. Plant/bird species richness and biodiversity measurement will employ the well-established Shannon Diversity and Simpson Indexes and Evar Evenness Index. Trained graduate students will also make observations of signs of care and the System for Observing Play and Recreation in Communities (SOPARC). SOPARC provides an assessment of park users’ PA levels, gender, activity types, and estimated age and ethnicity groupings as well as information on a park’s level of accessibility, usability, supervision, and organization with a high internal correlation between items (r=0.75), and exhibiting high inter-rater reliability (0.80-0.99). All nine parks, each of which consists of only one target area due their small size, will be observed twice over one day (9am-2pm) during randomly scheduled days without rain in summer months, by two raters. INT and CNT parks will be observed at the same time on different days for parallel observations. Signs of care involve observations (presence/absence) of manmade and natural items in a park and provides a categorical quality rating for each item, which is based on qualitative work in Detroit. Second, we will measure visual greenness and negative visual exposures (signs of disorder) via 360° images captured along each park perimeter, using a mounted camera (Samsung Gear 360). Images will be used to measure visual greenness, by quantifying pixels of greenery using methods we developed. Images will also be used to assess negative exposures using Marco et al.’s neighbor disorder coding protocol, which has shown acceptable ICCs (0.41-0.60) for the mean level of subscales of physical disorder and decay and has also been validated (showing high correlations) with physical audits, police impressions, and neighborhood socioeconomic status. This virtual auditing approach has been validated across several samples. We will employ two weighting schemes to create individual-level visual exposures from the park measures. First, we will weight each exposure by the actual contact time spent within view of the park in the one-week observation time using the GPS data as described previously. Second, we will calculate the percentage of the viewshed occupied by the park, as seen from the participant’s home by capturing a 360° image from the front door of the home location. We will then create weights using these measures, to be applied to each of the visual exposures above. 

Neighborhood soundscapes. Positive and negative auditory exposures will be assessed by acoustic recordings collected by 90 AudioMoth v1.1.0 acoustic loggers (Open Acoustic Devices).  Nine devices will be placed at least 100 m apart randomly in a 500 m grid around each park, and one device will be placed inside each park. We will record for one week in June, corresponding with Audubon’s bird surveys, selecting days to standardize weather conditions. To predict negative auditory exposure, we will calculate environmental noise metrics known to relate to human annoyance, health, and perception including: LAeq,T (A-weighted equivalent sound level (L) over time); LAmax (maximum A-weighted equivalent L over time); LA10 and LA90 (A-weighted L exceeded 10 and 90% of time); LA10 - LA90, LDN (Day-Night average L, where night events receive a 10dB penalty); LDEN (Day-Evening-High equivalency L); roughness (temporal variation in amplitude), and sharpness (126-129). 
To examine positive auditory exposure, trained staff will count the number and duration of sound categories using observations of spectrograms in Raven Pro software (Cornell University, Ithaca, NY). Sound categories are ‘anthropogenic’ (e.g., vehicle, people), ‘geological’ (e.g., wind), and ‘biological’ (e.g., birdsong). Additionally, we will further categorize bird song to species, in order to generate species richness and diversity of the acoustic community. We will combine the duration/frequency and richness of biological with geological sounds into a metric of positive exposure. Using values of each acoustic exposure metric, we will then predict levels throughout the study area using spatial kriging models. We will extract the positive and negative exposure levels for participants at each time point. 

Weather data. While we restrict data collection to summer months (May-September), weather conditions at the time of data collection and the two weeks prior to data collection may influence both exposures of interest and outcomes. Thus, we will compile daily precipitation and high temperature data for every day during data collection and the two weeks preceding data collection for each time point, from the weather station at Detroit airport (DTW).

registration_responses.q19.question:
Assuming a longitudinal panel design, we will compare intervention parks (INT) to control parks (CNT) at baseline using as appropriate ANOVA-F-tests, chi-square tests and non-parametric tests to determine equivalence of potentially confounding physiological and contextual participant characteristics. If substantive differences are found, they will be controlled for in subsequent analyses by regression techniques, guided by the degree of dissimilarity. Equivalence between groups will be assessed on age, sex, ethnicity, employment status, length of residence, marital status, attitudes towards nature, perceived safety, and pre-existing health conditions. We will calculate descriptive statistics for all variables at baseline and each post-restoration time point. Likewise, park characteristics will be summarized for the intervention and control parks for each time point.

We adopt a regression-based approach to multivariable modeling that addresses features of clustering of participants within parks and correlation over time in repeated assessments. Repeated measures ANOVA, or more apropos, generalized linear (mixed) models (GLMM) will be used. Denoted by an outcome in the i-th participant in the h-th park assessed at time t. It is assumed that an individual is primarily exposed to one park. Generally, outcomes are assessed at baseline and at least 3 additional time-points. The covariates are participant characteristics, some of which are time-invariant such as the aforementioned sociodemographic variables. Minimally, the predictor variables are: a single indicator for GROUP, with CNT as referent, three indicators for TIME, corresponding to t=1, 2, 3 with baseline t=0 as referent, and GROUPxTIME interactions. A measure of exposure to environmental stimuli is included in participant characteristics. The GLMM allows us to formulate and test hypotheses on functions of the regression parameters, including:  i) point-in-time comparison between INT and CNT, e.g., at each follow-up year;  ii) time-averaged comparison between INT and CNT;  iii) within group comparison for change over time; and  iv) change in INT compared to the corresponding change in CNT via DID. SAS Software v9.4 (Analytics 15.1 or higher) will be used for statistical analyses.
 
 Below, we outline specific analyses for each hypothesis to be tested.

Hypothesis 1: We will separately evaluate average activity counts/minute and average moderate-to-vigorous minutes over the one-week observation period for each of the data collection periods. The predictor of interest is binary: INT versus CNT.
Hypothesis 2: The primary outcome, ‘green PA’, will be average activity counts/minute and average moderate-to-vigorous minutes over the one-week observation period while in parks and greenspaces in Detroit, as a subset of all activity.
Hypothesis 3: We hypothesize there will be an association between PA and the visual and auditory exposures. Instead of a binary predictor of interest, we will use continuous predictors for visual and auditory park exposures. Interaction terms between positive and negative exposures will also be assessed, as evidence suggests that negative sounds deplete the restorative benefits of natural sounds, and that parks are often dominated by noise. 
Hypothesis 4: Each stress outcome will be evaluated separately and treated continuously. We will also explore potential mediators (e.g., PA) by adding each to mixed models as fixed terms, and adjusted mediation and partial correlation coefficients explored. We will adjust for prescription medication history and symptoms of acute illness as potential confounders.
Hypothesis 5: We will assess relationships with each stress indicator, in turn.
Hypothesis 6: We hypothesize there will be an association between each stress indicator and these exposures. 
Hypothesis 7: We will compare INT and CNT groups from baseline through three-years post-restoration for changes in CRP and A1C (continuously measured) between INT and CNT groups. We will also consider the inclusion of prescription medication history and symptoms of acute illness as potential confounders.
Hypothesis 8: We will compare INT and CNT groups from baseline through three-years post-restoration for changes in blood pressure, hip-to-waist ratio and BMI (continuously measured) between INT and CNT groups.

attributes.title: Perceived Warmth of the Outgroup Moderates the Effect of Intergroup Apologies
attributes.description: A 3-way experiment testing the moderating effect of offendedness on the influence of the warmth x apology interaction in intergroup conflicts.
attributes.registration_supplement: Pre-Registration in Social Psychology (van 't Veer & Giner-Sorolla, 2016): Pre-Registration

question10b.value:
Method
Participants. Based on the effect size obtained in a previous study (f = 0.15), with alpha = .05, power = .90, this 2 × 2× 2 experiment requires a sample size of 469. Participants who identify as British nationals aged 18 or above will be recruited via Prolific Academic (www.prolific.ac) and will receive approximately £1.42 in exchange for participation. We will exclude participants who fail at least one attention check item, and report being “not at all offended” by the incident. 
Procedure. Participants will first read a Wikipedia-style article that either describes East Timorese as highly sociable (high warmth condition) or unsociable (low warmth condition). Following the warmth manipulation, participants will complete attention checks, and measures of warmth and trust. Participants will then read a fictitious news article titled, “East Timor to investigate abuse of British tourists during custom checks,” which describes the fictional offense based on a real-world incident of alleged abuse of a Taiwanese tour group in Vietnam (DeAeth, 2019). The article will recount that a group of British tourists visiting East Timor were harassed and coerced into paying bribes to customs and immigration officials. The article will also mention that female travelers reported being inappropriately touched by male security officials. The article will also contain the apology manipulation. Participants will either be informed that East Timor has issued an official apology (apology condition) or that it was yet to issue an official apology (no-apology condition). Participants will be asked to indicate whether they were “not at all,” “somewhat,” or “very” offended by the incident. As in two previous experiments, the “not at all” participants will be excluded from further analyses. Participants will then complete the measure of forgiveness towards East Timorese in general. Finally, participants will be debriefed, in writing, about the true purpose of the study and thanked for their participation.
Materials.
Apology manipulation. In the no-apology condition, participants will read, “Following the official inquiry from the UK, the East Timorese government pledged to launch an investigation into the accusations but is yet to issue an official apology.” Participants in the apology condition will read, “Following the official inquiry from the UK, the East Timorese government issued an apology and pledged to launch an investigation into the accusations.” They will be presented with the full text of the ostensible apology. 
Warmth manipulation. In the high warmth condition, East Timorese will be described as warm, friendly, and sociable people who enjoy spending time with others, greet friends and family with a big hug and openly smile and talk to strangers. Participants in the low-warmth condition will read that East Timorese are unfriendly, cold, and unsociable people who prefer doing things alone, are reserved in their interactions with others and never smile or talk to strangers. The warmth manipulation will not contain morality-related information.  
Perceived warmth. Participants will rate the extent to which they consider East Timorese to be “friendly,” “well-intentioned,” “trustworthy,” “warm,” “good-natured,” and “sincere” on a scale of 1 (not at all) to 5 (extremely). Items will be averaged to form a single perceived warmth measure.  
Trust. Trust will be measured using five items adapted from Noor, James Brown, and Prentice (2008). Items are “Most members of the East Timorese community try to be fair,” “Few members of the East Timorese can be trusted,” (reverse-scored) “Most of the East Timorese do not deliberately mislead,” “Most members of the East Timorese community cannot be trusted to deliver on their promises” (reverse-scored) and “Trying to look for their own advantage is the main interest of most members of the East Timorese community” (reverse-scored). Items will be rated on a seven-point Likert-scale, anchored at 1 (strongly disagree) and 7 (strongly agree), and will be averaged to obtain a composite trust score.
Offendedness. Participants will be asked “How offended were you by the incident described in the passage?” and will indicate whether they are “not at all,” “somewhat” or “very much” offended. Those who report being “not at all offended” will be removed from further analyses.
Forgiveness. Forgiveness towards East Timorese will be measured using six items. Four items are adapted from Wohl et al. (2012): “I forgive the East Timorese for the harm done to the British,” “I don’t hold any negative feelings toward the East Timorese for their actions,” “I forgive the East Timorese for their role in this incident,” “It is not possible for me to forgive the actions of the East Timorese” (reverse-scored). We will also include two items adapted from Wohl and Branscombe (2005): “East Timorese should be forgiven for what their group did to the British,” and “British people should move past their negative feelings toward East Timorese for the harm their group inflicted” (1 = strongly disagree and 7 = strongly agree). Items were averaged to obtain a composite forgiveness score.
Perceived remorse. Following Philpot and Hornsey (2011), the question stem “To what extent do you think the response of the East Timorese was due to” will be paired with “feeling remorseful” and “truly being sorry” to form a measure of perceived remorse. Items will be rated on a 7-point scale anchored at 1 (not at all) and 7 (very much). 
Statistical analysis. We will conduct a 2 (apology) × 2 (warmth) × 2 (offendedness) between-subjects ANOVA on forgiveness and perceived remorse scores. Significance of pairwise comparisons will be judged based on Tukey-adjusted p-values. Indirect effects will be tested using bootstrapping procedures, with 1,000 resamples.

question1a.value: 1. We hypothesize a 3-way interaction (apology x warm x offendedness); that the perceived warmth of an offending outgroup would moderate both the apology-remorse and apology-forgiveness relationships. This interaction will further be moderated by the degree of offendedness. We specifically predict that an apology will elicit greater remorse and forgiveness when the apologizing (offending) group is perceived as warm than when it was perceived as lacking warmth. This relationship will only be seen among those who are highly offended by the offense. 2. We hypothesize an indirect effect of warmth on forgiveness through perceived remorse. 2. We hypothesize an indirect effect of warmth on forgiveness through perceived remorse.

question2a.value: We predict that among participants who are very offended (compared to those who are somewhat offended), perceived warmth will have a significant positive impact on both remorse and forgiveness such that participants in the high warmth condition will infer greater remorse following an apology as well as forgive the offending group more compared to participants in the low warmth condition. Among those who are highly offended, forgiveness and remorse will be highest among those who perceive the apologizing group as warm.

question3a.value: We are manipulating two variables, warmth (high vs low) and apology (high vs low). We include manipulation check variables for both and we predict both checks will find significant between-group differences. Offendedness is not manipulated but measured. This is because we maintain that the extent a person is offended by an intergroup incident is highly subjective.

Perceived remorse. Following Philpot and Hornsey (2011), the question stem “To what extent do you think the response of the East Timorese was due to” will be paired with “feeling remorseful” and “truly being sorry” to form a measure of perceived remorse. Items were rated on a 7-point scale anchored at 1 (not at all) and 7 (very much).

We will conduct a 2 (apology) × 2 (warmth) × 2 (offendedness) between-subjects ANOVA on forgiveness and perceived remorse scores. Significance of pairwise comparisons will be judged based on Tukey-adjusted p-values. Where appropriate, simple slopes analysis will also be used to probe significant interactions.

IV: apology
Moderators: warmth, offendedness
DV: forgiveness, perceived remorse
registration_responses.confirmatory-analyses-third.third.questi: Trust. Trust will be measured using five items adapted from Noor, James Brown, and Prentice (2008). Items are “Most members of the East Timorese community try to be fair,” “Few members of the East Timorese can be trusted,” (reverse-scored) “Most of the East Timorese do not deliberately mislead,” “Most members of the East Timorese community cannot be trusted to deliver on their promises” (reverse-scored) and “Trying to look for their own advantage is the main interest of most members of the East Timorese community” (reverse-scored). Items will be rated on a seven-point Likert-scale, anchored at 1 (strongly disagree) and 7 (strongly agree), and will be averaged to obtain a composite trust score.
t-test, comparing the trust between the high vs low warmth groups.

attributes.title: A case of real-life moral dilemmas: a cross-cultural longitudinal study during the corona pandemic
attributes.description: Even though there is a large amount of research on moral decision-making, most dilemmas that are used are very abstract from real life (e.g. trolley dilemmas). In case of the corona virus outbreak in late 2019/ early 2020 in that started in Wuhan, China there suddenly is a pandemic crisis that affects the whole world and poses a variety of real-life moral dilemmas. Even more interestingly, these moral dilemmas occur on different levels. Some are personal, some are posed on structural and societal levels, including economic decision-making. The goal of the current study is to investigate how moral decision-making is influenced by personal exposure to a crisis, how personal and timely proximity plays a role and how it is perceived in three different societies (Iran, Italy, Germany) that have different peaks of the outbreak and a different approach of dealing with the situation by their respective governments.

q1.value: A case of real-life moral dilemmas: a cross-cultural longitudinal study during the corona pandemic

q2.value: Ronja Demel, Francesco Grassi, Yasaman Rafiee, Annekathrin Schacht

q3.value: Even though there is a large amount of research on moral decision-making, most dilemmas that are used are very abstract from real life (e.g. trolley dilemmas). The criticism of the lack of external validity and low plausibility has been much discussed for trolley dilemmas but is at the same time difficult to overcome (Bauman, McGraw, Bartels, & Warren, 2014; Körner, Joffe, & Deutsch, 2019). In the case of the novel corona virus (nCOVID-19) outbreak in late 2019/ early 2020 that started in Wuhan, China there suddenly is a pandemic crisis that affects the whole world and poses a variety of real-life moral dilemmas. Even more interestingly, these moral dilemmas occur on different levels. Some are personal, some are posed on structural and societal levels, including economic decision-making. The goal of the current study is to investigate how moral decision-making is influenced by personal exposure to a crisis, how personal and timely proximity plays a role and how it is perceived in three different societies (Iran, Italy, Germany) that have different peaks of the outbreak and a different approach of dealing with the situation by their respective governments. As studies have shown that the level of relationship to a threatened other can alter moral decision-making (e.g. Topolski, Weaver, Martin, and McCoy, 2013), we do expect that personal affectedness will modulate the decision-making process. Furthermore, previous research indicates that there are demographic differences, such as age or education that modulate how much people adapt to protective behavior measures (Bish & Michie, 2010). These differences based on demographics might also be observable in the moral decision-making.

q4.value:
We do expect a difference between personal and institutional scenarios

Personal scenarios
•	For time-point 1 we expect that the more the person is affected himself or herself or they or their family members are part of a risk group, the more likely they will choose to help the individual (deontological choice). The farther away it is perceived by the person (low anxiety, no affected or infected family members), the more utilitarian their answer behavior will be
•	For time points 2 and 3 (after 2 and 4 months), we do expect a shift to more deontological choices in general compared to utilitarian choices, e.g. saving those in need/the weak/the ones who are needing help first.
•	For time-point 1 we expect that the more uncertain people feel about the situation, the more deontological they will choose in personal dilemmas, i.e. getting help to the ones with severe symptoms first and justifying on stocking up on food and medical supplies

Institutional (and mixed) scenarios
•	For the institutional scenarios, we expect different answer patterns for the 3 time-points. For time point 1 we expect that people judge in a more utilitarian way (companies should not have higher profits and they should only be able to provide medical institutions with supplies) as compared to time-point 2 and 3 
•	We expect differences based on /the severance of the pandemic at time-point 1 and the political management of the crisis by the different countries that will be observed.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: The study is based on the worldwide outbreak of the novel corona virus (nCOVID-19) at the end of 2019 and early 2020. Based on moral scenarios that are relevant in relation to the pandemic, we will present five short moral scenarios, 2 on a personal, 2 on an institutional level and one mixed (personal and institutional component) scenario. In addition, we will ask a number of demographic questions (age, gender, educational background, occupation, nationality, country of residence, pre-existing medical conditions, religiousness) and 4 additional question aiming at the perceived certainty of the situation, the fear of the virus and own affectedness. The study is longitudinal with three test points. Test point 1 starts at the peak of the crisis in mid-March 2020 for a testing-period of 10 days. The testing-period for test-point 2 starts after 60 days of the first period and test point 3 after 120 days, both for a period of 10 days. The study will be conducted in three different countries: Germany, Italy and Iran. For Germany, the questionnaire is translated into German, for Italy it is presented in Italian and for Iran it is presented in Farsi. The exact questions are specified below under variables.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Data will be collected online through the open source framework formr (Arslan, Tata & Walther, 2018). Participants will be able to perform the study on their computers or mobile devices. Eligible participants will be Germans, Italians, and Iranians who are 18 years or older. Participants will be recruited through the ANaP-Lab database, online posts and through social media. All participants will have to give their informed consent in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki by pressing an “I agree” button located beneath an explanatory letter. For Germans, the questionnaire will be in German, for subjects in Italy, it will be in Italian and for Iranians, it will be in Farsi.

q13.value: We will test as many participants as possible through an online questionnaire during the three test-points for a duration of 10 days for each test-point.

q14.value: The study is based on the Corona virus outbreak; therefore, there is no specific number of participants pre-defined. We will test as many participants as possible for a duration of 10 days per time-point in each of the three target countries.

q15.value: We have a stopping rule based on time. For each time-point, we will collect data for a duration of 10 days. As we expect a large amount of dropouts, we will not have any other stopping rule.

question.value:
Measured variables 
•	Personal 1: A registered GP is already 65 years old. In his medical practice, he usually treats many patients including vulnerable patient groups. He is now considering closing his practice during the pandemic as he is in high risk due to his age. How acceptable is it for him to close down the practice?
•	0= very unacceptable
•	100= very acceptable
-->This question will be answered on a scale from 0-100 with a preference for one of the two options as the ends of the scale.
•	Personal 2: The pandemic hit and markets are running out of medical supplies (masks, disinfections) and canned food. How acceptable is it to stock up on medical supplies and food for you personally even though this might lead to shortages for other people? 
•	0=Very acceptable
•	100=Very unacceptable
-->This question will be answered on a scale from 0-100 with a preference for one of the two options as the ends of the scale.
•	Institutional 1: Wufa is a medical company specialized in the production of disinfectants and medical masks. Should they be restricted from selling their products to the public and only be able to sell to medical institutions during the pandemic?
•	100=Definitely yes
•	0= Definitely no
-->This question will be answered on a scale from 0-100 with a preference for one of the two options as the ends of the scale.
•	Institutional 2: Should Wufa be able to raise prices for disinfectants and medical masks during the pandemic as there is an increased demand, thereby increasing its own profit margin?
•	100= Definitely yes
•	0= Definitely no
-->This question will be answered on a scale from 0-100 with a preference for one of the two options as the ends of the scale. 
•	Mixed scenario (both personal and institutional implications): “Prioritizing patients”: In the situation of the current Corona Pandemic, hospitals (in Germany, Italy, Iran) are currently overfilled. 1000 Patients with symptoms show up but immediate treatment is only available for 500 patients. How should patients be prioritized?
•	0= Young ones and otherwise healthy ones should be prioritized as they have a higher chance of survival, so the treatment is most likely more effective.
•	100= Older ones and people with pre-existing conditions should be prioritized and given health care first as they are in a higher risk of dying, however, their risk of dying even with the treatment is a lot higher.
-->This question will be answered on a scale from 0-100 with a preference for one of the two options as the ends of the scale

Demographics: 
•	Age (answered in years from 18-100)
•	Gender (male, female, other)
•	Occupation (occupation categories, e.g. health care)
•	Educational background (none, primary education, secondary education, Bachelors, Masters, PhD or higher, other)
•	Nationality (Iranian, Italian, German, other)
•	Country of residence (Iran, Italy, Germany, other)
•	Own pre-existing conditions (Yes/No, if yes, specifiy from selection)
•	Are you or do you know someone who is or was infected? (Yes, me/ yes, someone else/ No)
•	How confident do you feel about the situation concerning of the Corona virus? (Scale 0: not at all confident, 100: very confident)
•	How afraid are you of being infected? (0= not afraid, 100= very afraid)
•	How afraid are you of you or someone close to you dying due to the corona virus? (0= not afraid, 100= very afraid)
•	Religiousness: how religious are you? (0= not religious, 100= very religious)
For our main questions, we will compute the mean and standard deviations.

We will use a linear mixed model for each of the five target questions separately for time-point 1 with nationality and gender as between-subject factors and personal affectedness, religiousness, certainty and age as covariates. 

In a second analysis, we will use a linear mixed model for each of the target questions separately with nationality, gender and time-point as between-subject factors and age as covariate.

q21.value: Standard p-values of .05 will be used as a cut-off. Two-tailed tests will be used.

q22.value: We will exclude data that is not complete for the time-point 1.

q24.value: Differences between countries will be assessed in an exploratory manner. Further exploratory analyses might be appropriate and applicable due to the uncertain outcome of the crisis at the point of writing the pre-registration.

q25.value: Since the outcome of the pandemic is uncertain, we might adjust the analysis plan accordingly.

attributes.title: Expression and Prognostics Significance of MT1 isoforms in Clear Cell Renal Cell Carcinoma
attributes.description: Metallothioneins (MTs), a family of low-weight cysteine-rich proteins, play key roles in tumor biology, such as proliferation, differentiation, apoptosis, and drug resistance. Clinical studies have demonstrated that deregulation of MTs in various types of solid cancers. However, a comprehensive overview of MT1 isoforms expression and clinical relevance in clear cell renal cell cancer (ccRCC) is lacking. The present study explored mRNA expression levels and prognostic values of MT1 isoforms in ccRCC tissues using The Cancer Genome Atlas (TCGA), Gene Expression Profiling and Interactive Analysis (GEPIA) and Oncomine database. The study observed that mRNA expression levels of six members of MT1 isoforms decreased in renal cancer tumor tissues compared with normal tissues. We further found that high-expression of MT1G, MT1H, MT1F and MT1X was related with poor overall survival time in ccRCC patients and high-expression of MT1G, MT1F and MT1X were inversely associated with disease-free survival time in ccRCC patients. Based on the correlation analysis, MT1G was identified to be co-expressed with MT1H and MT1F in ccRCC tissues. These findings suggested that MT1 isoforms mRNA may serve as diagnostic and prognostic markers for ccRCC.

q2.value: The present study aimed to explore mRNA expression status of MT1 isoforms and their prognostic significance in ccRCC. For this purpose, we firstly investigated mRNA expression levels of MT1 isoforms in human ccRCC using The Cancer Genome Atlas (TCGA), Gene Expression Profiling and Interactive Analysis (GEPIA) and Oncomine database. Secondly, prognostic value of MT1 isoforms mRNA expression in ccRCC patients was evaluated through GEPIA by analyzing clinical data from the TCGA-KIRC project. Finally, correlations of MT1G with other MT1 isoforms were conducted using the R program to show the correlation in ccRCC.

attributes.title: TimeSocialDistancing
attributes.description: First weeks of initialization for this project. Additional contributors are already being added and expected to expand in the course of the project.

q1.value: Virginie van Wassenhove, Fuat Balcı, Anne Giersch, Claude Gronfier, Argiro Vatakis

q3.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
Questionnaires: 
•	Environment and social connectivity (UCLA)
•	Isolation questionnaire
•	Morningness-Eveningness Chronotype	(rMEQ)
•	Zimbardo Time Perspective Inventory 
•	Hospital Anxiety and Depression Scale (HADS)
•	Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index (PSQI)
•	Big Five Inventory (BFI-10)
•	Attentional Style Questionnaire (ASQ) 
•	Self Perception
•	Daily sleep quality 


Examples of tasks are: 
-	Mackworth Clock Task: unbeknownst to the participants, the speed of the clock will be normal (1 sec), slowed (1.2 s) or fastened (0.8 s). The working hypothesis is that participant will not explicitly notice the change of speed due to task requirements, but vigilance may be affected by speed changes.
-	Temporal metacognition: the accuracy and precision of temporal production, as well as the capacity for temporal metacognition will be impaired during social distancing.
-	Tapping: the capacity to synchronize to external cues may be impaired during social distancing. 
-	Temporal discounting: temporal discounting will be improved with the capacity to self-project outside of the social distancing.

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
We will sample from an adult consenting and voluntary population recruited for online experiments, that have been approved by the Ethical committee of each implicated country. Participants will complete a short questionnaire providing basic demographic information together with information about the study. All information will remain fully anonymous. An informed consent will be collected prior to the data collection.
Following the completion of initial questionnaires, participants will be invited to login to the server and complete as many tasks as they wish at the pace they wish in each session. A total of 5 sessions in the course of the confinement period will be collected. 
We aim to collect longitudinal data so that each task will be five times per participant during confinement and three times in post-confinement period (1 or 2 weeks after, 3 months and 6 months after)

Responses to questionnaires, performances, ratings, and chronometric data will be collected.

q11.value: Participants will be recruited until the end of the social distanciation period and after. As many participants as possible will be recruited within this period, up to 500 per country.

q12.value: Due to the exploratory nature of the study containing several types of tasks and questionnaires, a power analysis is difficult at this stage.  We will aim for significant effects explaining at least 5% or more of the shared variance between the longitudinal measurements. Multivariate correlations between longitudinal changes in chronobiology, temporal cognition, and general well-being and sleep-pattern during and after social distancing.

q13.value: A control group will be collected matching the initial sample tested both during social distancing and after. Financial factors may contribute.

Examples of tasks are: 
-	Mackworth Clock Task: unbeknownst to the participants, the speed of the clock will be normal (1 sec), slowed (1.2 s) or fastened (0.8 s). The working hypothesis is that participant will not explicitly notice the change of speed due to task requirements, but vigilance may be affected by speed changes.
-	Temporal metacognition: the accuracy and precision of temporal production, as well as the capacity for temporal metacognition will be impaired during social distancing.
-	Tapping: the capacity to synchronize to external cues may be impaired during social distancing. 
-	Temporal discounting: temporal discounting will be improved with the capacity to self-project outside of the social distancing.
registration_responses.q10.question:
We will sample from an adult consenting and voluntary population recruited for online experiments, that have been approved by the Ethical committee of each implicated country. Participants will complete a short questionnaire providing basic demographic information together with information about the study. All information will remain fully anonymous. An informed consent will be collected prior to the data collection.
Following the completion of initial questionnaires, participants will be invited to login to the server and complete as many tasks as they wish at the pace they wish in each session. A total of 5 sessions in the course of the confinement period will be collected. 
We aim to collect longitudinal data so that each task will be five times per participant during confinement and three times in post-confinement period (1 or 2 weeks after, 3 months and 6 months after)

Responses to questionnaires, performances, ratings, and chronometric data will be collected.
