attributes.title: Investigating the relationship between emotional granularity and cardiovascular physiology in daily life
attributes.description: In this project, we test the hypothesis that emotional granularity (a measure of the precision of an individual’s emotion concepts) is significantly positively correlated with resting respiratory sinus arrhythmia (RSA; used as an index of parasympathetic activity and proxy measure of efficient allostasis) as measured in daily life. We further investigate the nature of this relationship by characterizing patterns of cardiovascular activity during resting periods and emotional events, including and in comparison with measures of emotional granularity.

q1.value: Investigating the relationship between emotional granularity and cardiovascular physiology in daily life: Classification analyses

q2.value: Katie Hoemann, Zulqarnain Khan, Karen Quigley, Lisa Feldman Barrett

q3.value: Previous research has used supervised machine learning approaches to classify physiological data according to the type of emotional event it represents. However, the data used in these analyses has not been collected in an idiographic manner, such that each individual's data may represent instances from different emotions (i.e., classes). Accordingly, these analyses have not been able to examine whether individual differences in emotional granularity might correspond with the performance of a classifier trained on participants' own data. This is an important distinction, as, in theory, individuals with higher granularity may not evidence the same patterns of physiological activity as individuals with lower granularity; as such, comparing classifier performance on nomothetically-supervised data (e.g., trained to identify instances of induced anger or fear) may not yield meaningful results. In these analyses, we submit cardiovascular data recorded during experience sampling events to participant-specific classification analyses supervised by the most frequent words each participant generated to label these events. Then, we compare classifier performance across participants, with the hypothesis that performance measures improve along with emotional granularity.

q4.value: Classifier performance will positively correlate with emotional granularity, such that participants with higher granularity have patterns of physiological activity during emotional events that can be more accurately classified (where accuracy is determined by the participants' own self-generated labels for the same events).

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
As part of a larger study on affective experience and decision making in daily life, 52 participants completed approximately 14, eight-hour days of ambulatory peripheral physiological monitoring. 

Each day, participants visited the lab and were outfitted with sensors and portable equipment to measure their electrocardiogram (ECG) and impedance cardiogram (ICG) as well as bodily movement and posture (via accelerometers). A custom-built smartphone application initiated an experience sampling prompt any time the interbeat interval (IBI; also called heart period) changed by more than ±167ms over an eight-second period, with these thresholds adjusted per participant to ensure they received a comparable number of prompts per day. Prompts were not generated if participants had moved substantially or shifted posture within the proceeding 30s. At each sampling event, participants were prompted to respond to a series of questions presented in smartphone application, including to freely list and provide intensity ratings for their experienced emotions. 

Upon completing experience sampling each day, participants automatically received an end-of-day survey, which they used to provide additional details about the prompts they completed throughout the day. As part of this survey, participants rated each emotional event on a set of 18 standard emotions.

q10.value: Registration following analysis of the data

q11.value: The physiological data of interest have already been analyzed using both unsupervised (Hoemann et al, 2020) and supervised (Azari et al, 2020) machine learning methods. We will use the results of previous classification analyses as input to the present analyses, where we will compare them with measures of emotional granularity, as described below.

question.value:
Sixty-seven participants ranging in age from 18-36 years (55% female; 38.8% White, 3.0% Black, 29.8% Asian, 28.4% other; M = 22.8 years, SD = 4.4 years) were recruited from the greater Boston area through posted advertisements, as well as Northeastern University classrooms and online portals. Eligible participants were non-smoking, fluent English-speakers, and excluded if they had a history of cardiovascular illness or stroke, chronic medical conditions, mental illness, asthma, skin allergies, or very sensitive skin. Eligible participants also confirmed they were not taking any medications known to influence physiological arousal including medications for ADHD, insomnia, anxiety, hypertension, rheumatoid arthritis, epilepsy/seizures, cold/flu, or fever/allergies. Participants received $490 as compensation for completing all parts of the study, plus up to an additional $55 in compliance and task incentives. 

Of the 67 recruited participants, six withdrew and an additional nine were dismissed due to poor compliance. A total of 52 participants completed the full protocol (56% female; 38.5% White, 1.9% Black, 38.5% Asian, 21.2% other; M = 22.5 years, SD = 4.4 years). 

Each participant completed approximately 14 days (M = 14.4, SD = 0.6) of context-aware experience sampling distributed across a three- to four-week period (M = 24.9 days, SD = 5.5 days). On each day of experience sampling, participants came into the lab and were instrumented for peripheral physiological recordings. Participants were instructed to continue physiological recordings for eight hours each day, after which they were able to remove and recharge all equipment. Upon completing experience sampling each day, participants automatically received an end-of-day survey, which they used to provide additional details about the prompts they completed throughout the day. Before and after the two-week experience sampling protocol, participants also completed two in-lab sessions. The data from these in-lab sessions are not relevant to the present analyses.

q13.value: A total of 52 participants completed the full protocol (56% female; 38.5% White, 1.9% Black, 38.5% Asian, 21.2% other; M = 22.5 years, SD = 4.4 years). Each participant completed approximately 14 days (M = 14.4, SD = 0.6) of context-aware experience sampling.

question.value:
Participants were prompted to label their experience via a smartphone application when they exhibited a pronounced and sustained change in interbeat interval (IBI; i.e., the time between successive heart beats) in the absence of physical movement. During each sampling event, participants freely labeled their current emotional experience. At the end of the day, participants received a survey asking them to provide additional information about each emotional event, including intensity ratings to a standard set of 18 emotions.

We analyzed physiological data from 60-s windows (30 s before and after a change in IBI); these are the event-level data. For each of these events, we derived change scores (i.e., the difference between the 30 s preceding the event trigger and the 30 s after) for the following six cardiovascular measures:
- Inter-beat interval (IBI)
- Respiratory sinus arrhythmia (RSA)
- Pre-ejection period (PEP)
- Left ventricular ejection time (LVET)
- Stroke volume (SV)
- Cardiac output (CO)
Data were analyzed following the signal processing and feature extraction pipeline outlined in Hoemann et al (2020, January 14) - see Other section for full citation. 

We used the freely-generated emotion labels from the experience sampling events to supervise the classification analysis. Specifically, we used each participant's top 3 most frequent labels, and select the corresponding physiological data. 

Separately, we will also analyze the intensity endorsements to 18 standard emotion terms from the end-of-day surveys. For each event, participants rated the following emotions on a 7-point Likert style scale from 0 ('not at all') to 6 ('very much') : “afraid”, “amused”, “angry”, “bored”, “calm”, “disgusted”, “embarrassed”, “excited”, “frustrated”, “grateful”, “happy”, “neutral”, “proud”, “relieved”, “sad”, “serene”, “surprised”, and “worn out”.

For each period seated rest, we derived the mean across all 30-s bins, such that we have one measure of IBI, RSA, RR, and PEP for each resting period. We then took the mean and standard deviation across all resting periods for a given participant.

For the experience sampling data, we will derive an index of emotional granularity using intra-class correlations (ICCs) using the 'A-k' method (absolute agreement with averaged raters). We will calculate separate ICCs for ratings of positively-valenced emotion (e.g., happy, calm, grateful) and negatively-valenced emotions (e.g., angry, sad, afraid); we will use the mean of these to represent overall granularity. ICC values will be Fisher transformed and inverted (i.e., multiplied by -1, such that most positive values represent higher granularity). ICCs will be calculated across all data for a given participant.

We have already conducted a supervised analysis of this data using each participant's 3 most commonly used emotion words as a priori labels, and the physiological data from the corresponding events. An average of 72.73 (SD=28.46) events were used for classification per participant (minimum=33, maximum=158). We trained and tuned a fully-connected neural network using 5-fold cross-validation, diving each participant's data into 5 groups and iterating across all combinations of training on 4/5ths of the data, and testing on the left-out 1/5th. Mean participant-level accuracy was calculated by averaging across all cross-validation folds. 

In the present analysis, we will correlate mean participant-level classification accuracy against participant-level estimates of emotional granularity.

q21.value: We will use the standard alpha of .05 for determining if the above-described correlation is significant. We will use a two-tailed analysis.

q22.value: Following Hoemann et al (2020, January 14), we reviewed ECG data to confirm IBI series values are within acceptable ranges (300-2000ms) and that expected beat-to-beat differences were consistent with normal beats and unlikely to be artifacts. ECG data failing any quality check with were excluded from analysis. We likewise excluded ICG data in which B and X points could not be detected or that corresponded to periods of unusable ECG data. Quality checks were also performed on PEP and LVET features; we retained only values that occurred within an acceptable range (30-200ms for PEP, 100-500ms for LVET), and that did not result in changes in the gradient greater than 30ms from one ensemble to the next.

q23.value: To ensure comparability of results across the sample, we excluded participants who had fewer than 70 events devoid of major physiological artifact. This resulted in the removal of six participants, resulting in a final sample size of 46 (50% female; 43.5% White, 0% Black, 41.3% Asian, 15.2% other; Mage = 22.4 years, SDage = 4.4 years).

q25.value:
Research using these same data has been published to PsyArXiv as:

Hoemann, K., Khan, Z., Feldman, M., Nielson, C., Devlin, M., Dy, J., … Quigley, K. (2020, January 14). Context-aware experience sampling reveals the scale of variation in affective experience. https://doi.org/10.31234/osf.io/cvjb8

Azari, B., Westlin, C., Satpute, A. B., Hutchinson, J. B., Kragel, P. A., ... Barrett, L. B. (2020, March 19). Finding what you are looking for: Comparing supervised and unsupervised approaches to emotion categorization. https://doi.org/10.31234/osf.io/egh2t.

attributes.title: A Preference for Error-Inducing Price Complexity

data.value: It's complicated. We have already collected some data but explain in Question 8 why readers may consider this a valid pre-registration nevertheless.

other.value:
We may use attitudinal measures to explore relationships in secondary analyses.
Note that we have already collected 50 observations. A large number of subjects reported in a free text response box some beliefs about the points disclosures that reflected misconceptions about the disclosures. We adjusted the instructions and will launch the full study (200 participants) next.

sample.value: We will collect 200 observations on MTurk.

analyses.value:
We will use proportions tests and logistic regressions with binary outcomes to identify:
1)The proportions of subjects who prefer the complex information display.
2) The proportions of subjects who successfully choose the highest-points-available option in the choice task.

outliers.value:
We will exclude participants who do not answer key dependent variables. 
In robustness checks, we may also exclude participants who do not pass an attention check and/or whose location cannot be verified to be unique.

dependent.value:
Preference: Participants will indicate whether they prefer information displayed in a relatively complex (vs. simple) way.

Choice in selection task: Whether or not participants successfully chose the option with the most points that could be earned.

conditions.value: Choice task: Subjects will be randomly assigned to complete an incentivized choice task (incentivized to pick the compensation scheme with the most points available) either with two simple or with two complex options.

hypothesis.value:
H1: Fewer than half of participants will prefer a more complex points disclosure. 

Unlike previous studies on price complexity, the “points” study has stripped away much of the context that we believe contributes to a preference for costly complexity. We believe a nontrivial number of participants will still prefer the complex points disclosure, but the number will be fewer than in previous studies. 

H2: Subjects will be more likely to select a lower-points (dominated) compensation scheme when points disclosures are complex. 

Because the points study disclosures are less complex than in previous studies, we believe the difference will not be as pronounced as in previous studies.

attributes.title: Can information about public opinion affect the likelihood that politicians support science-approved policies?

q1.value: Can information about public opinion affect the likelihood that politicians support science-approved policies?

q2.value: Daniel Butler | Elin Naurin | Patrik Öhberg

q5.value: This research is conducted with support from the Swedish Research Council within the realm of the project Citizen Influence on Individual Politicians in Party-centered Systems, project number 2017-01364. We are also grateful to the Laboratory of Opinion Research (LORE) at the University of Gothenburg and to IVL Swedish Environmental Research Institute for constructive collaborations.

q8.value: Registration prior to realization of outcomes

q15.value: Often scientific advice is ignored by policymakers. Some have advocated building support in the public as a way to get politicians to implement scientific recommendations. Is this likely to be effective? We look at whether informing politicians about the popularity of an issue affects their willingness to support implementing the policy. We specifically test if politicians change their behavior in response to information about the popularity of a proposal.

q16.value: In our experiment we gather information about public support for a science-based policy proposal. We then randomly assign Swedish politicians into three possible treatment groups: (1) A control group with no information, (2) A policy group that receives the information about the science-based policy recommendation, and (3) An opinion + policy group that receives the information about the science-based recommendation and the public support in their district for the recommendation.

q25.value: 22 May 2019; The panel of politicians used in this project function under an ethics approval that is renewed continuously. The latest renewal was 22 May 2019.
